body:
Did you read any of the [documentation](https://uber.github.io/ludwig/)? All of that is specified in the `model_definition.yaml` file. For example: 

```
input_features:
    -
        name: text
        type: text
        level: word
        encoder: parallel_cnn

output_features:
    -
        name: class
        type: category
```
This describes a text classifier which uses a [parallel CNN](https://uber.github.io/ludwig/user_guide/#parallel-cnn-encoder)

> Did you read any of the [documentation](https://uber.github.io/ludwig/)? All of that is specified in the `model_definition.yaml` file. For example:
> 
> ```
> input_features:
>     -
>         name: text
>         type: text
>         level: word
>         encoder: parallel_cnn
> 
> output_features:
>     -
>         name: class
>         type: category
> ```
> 
> This describes a text classifier which uses a [parallel CNN](https://uber.github.io/ludwig/user_guide/#parallel-cnn-encoder)

model_definition is predefined by me before training a ludwig model,not created by ludwig. what if I didn't define encoder in my model definition? which network structure would ludwig use?
@manesioz only input_features and output_features are necessary in model_definition.yaml, I'm allowed to train a ludwig model without defining encoder or decoder.

For the timeseries example, the [documentation](https://uber.github.io/ludwig/user_guide/#time-series-features) reads: 

> The encoders are the same used for the Sequence Features. 

And the sequence features [docs](https://uber.github.io/ludwig/user_guide/#sequence-input-features-and-encoders) specify that the default encoder is a `parallel_cnn`.  

In general: 
> A list of all the encoders available for all the datatypes alongside with the description of all parameters will be provided in the datatype-specific sections. Some datatypes have only one type of encoder, so you are not required to specify it.

So to answer your question, each encoder is datatype-specific and either only has one encoder available or has a default encoder. Each encoder has a variety of it's respective hyperparameters. 

Maybe @w4nderlust can go into more detail or correct me if I am missing something.

@msaisumanth even though i can find some hyperparameters in description.json, i still don't know the structure of my neural network. for example, the number of layer, the number of neuron. moreover, there is no encoder in my description.json.
![屏幕截图](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31396222/68101353-34131d80-ff08-11e9-843c-f0063bdb8351.jpg)
![屏幕截图1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31396222/68101356-38d7d180-ff08-11e9-9252-ff4b96a3cb8b.jpg)
![屏幕截图2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31396222/68101358-3bd2c200-ff08-11e9-814b-328511e6d306.jpg)

Every parameter that is not specified is assigned to be the default, which
is reported in the parentheses in the documentation of that parameter.
For instance the documentation for sequence encoders it says that the default is a `parallel_cnn` https://uber.github.io/ludwig/user_guide/#sequence-input-features-and-encoders and for the parallel cnn it says which are the default parameters https://uber.github.io/ludwig/user_guide/#parallel-cnn-encoder.

Deeper description of the built model can be obtained if logging level is
set to `DEBUG` when trainig.

Finally if you want to know all the operations that are happening in the
model, grouped by feature, you can look at the tensorboard grap tab. You
have to call the tensorboard command specifying the model path and
appending `/log` to the path like:
```
tensorboard --logdir results/experiment_run_0/model/log
```
replace the path with the one you obtained when training.

Let us know if you have further doubts.

P.S. Thank you @manesioz for helping answering.
What does not work? the tensorboard? that's just an example, you have to specify exactly the directory that contains the log of your training.

Is there any way to know how many layers my networks has? For example, I am building my network using the Python API and training a model with only numerical input features, but I think the default amount of layers (or how they are obtained) for that case is not specified in the documentation. I think the default amount of neuros is 256 per layer, but I am not sure.
